commentBody:
Where are the doctors who prescribed these pain killers? I would like to hear from them as well. What do they think about how this happened?
"In 2010, Scioto County would lead Ohio in the number of opioid prescriptions, with enough to give 123 pills to each resident."
Thank you for this very humanizing story.

In 1993, the DEA allowed pharmaceutical companies to manufacture 3,520 kilograms of oxycodone. In 2015, the DEA authorized production of 137,500 kilograms of oxycodone.

Why did the DEA keep approving such massive increases in the production of opioids?

What exactly is the incentive for the DEA to reduce drug abuse?

Even without the scourge of opioids most of these kids are doomed.  They lack the basic education to navigate in our increasingly complex economy and haven't mastered even elementary-school reading, reasoning and math skills.  But they sure know how to use a wicked texting thumb!  Robots will supplant many of the mook jobs that the blue-collar kids would have taken for granted.  What will they do?  Will the newly burgeoning cannabis economy absorb a lot of them?
This is the scariest and saddest article I have read in a long time.
Been getting high since 1968 and at age 83 I still enjoy it.

Where's the article about the class of majority black high school ravaged by drugs and violence and how the class of 2000 is doing? A war on drugs and mandatory minimums greeted troubled black children, but now that it is white children, it's a terrible loss of promising futures. Criminals, whether illegal drug pushers or criminals under the veneer of respectability, like the Sackler family, prey on the vulnerable for the same reason: money. The spotlight, empathy, and medical and community support should be equal for all victimized children.
only greed can result in devastation of this magnitude
Where was this outcry, empathy and understanding when the crack epidemic happened

Prescription opioid abuse has 4 perpetrators:
1. False advertising of the pharmaceutical companies
2. Over prescribing physicians
3. Individuals willfully taking opioids 
4. Government's war on drugs treating drug abuse as a crime rather than a medical condition
Until all 4 guilty parties take responsibility and take corrective action prescription opioid abuse will continue.

This was Indeed, a Most Insightful LOOK into this Class of 2000.
The Sad Story, is that it's ONLY Scratching the Surface of what lead these Youths, to take this Path in the 1'st place.
There is ONLY 1 Culprit, who facilitated this whole Opiate Addiction.

The way this article is presented really wakes you up to the insidious stranglehold that addiction has on so many victims. We can see ourselves or our children in the yearbook photos and school activities listed. It's frightening, sad, and angering at the same time. How did this great nation allow this to happen?
the devastation that greed can cause ...............

Good going, Boomer. You've made opioids, meth and heroin easily available to your children while drowning them in alcohol, 'behavioral' meds and War on Drugs hypocrisy. All while scrunching your noses up at the legalization of marijuana.

Combine this with being in a Republican-led "red" state that does not display legitimate concern for its own citizens but bows in open fealty to pharma/alcohol/law enforcement/political interests and you have a recipe for the rural i.e. white face of this "crisis".

Possible solutions:

* Vote only for Democratic candidates if you live in a 'red" state (or any state, for that matter)

* Hold the pharmaceutical interests to account for aggressively marketing such an addictive and dangerous hard drug

* Legalize/decriminalize pot. Offer free opioid addiction treatment to those who seek it and remove the criminal convictions of those convicted for marijuana use/possession offenses.

Start somewhere. Smoke 'em if you got 'em. Drink Responsibly. Avoid hard drugs. Have the day you deserve.
High-quality swing state voters.
Everyone is to blame but the kids who had been told exactly how addictive these drugs were many times were and took them anyway.
Congratulations on such a powerful piece of reportage.

I am afraid that we will read " The Class of "2019 Could Have Been Anything Until Vaping Hit'..."
We are making the same mistake about vaping epidemics.
I live in pain every day and have for years.  I walk hunched with a limp and a cane at age 63.  What do you think my chances are of obtaining these pain killers?  None.

I’m within a year in age of the subjects in this article. I grew up in a nearby state where I attended a middle class suburban high school about three times the size of this one. I never knew of a single person who was addicted to anything in high school or has become an addict since. I’m sure there have been some but I keep up with about 50 people from my ‘01 graduating class and to the best of my knowledge not one has had a problem with addiction, gone to rehab, or been in trouble with the law. I don’t feel the school in this story is representative of the typical graduating class from around the year 2000. 

In reading their stories I came away with that they each made a choice to take pills that were not prescribed to them or to continue to take medication when it was no longer needed. I’ve had many instances where I required this type of pain medication or stronger yet I’ve never become addicted simply because I took it when I was in pain and stopped when over the counter pain relief was enough. I’m concerned for those in true pain who are now being denied adequate pain relief because of choices other people have made. There are already stories of chronic pain patients who have taken their own lives when their doctors refused to continue their pain medication. They are the true victims here.

These pen-pictures indicate an undercurrent of a lack of social mobility in the area (the involvement of multiple extended families and cousins) and a innate acceptance or tolerance of drunk driving.  A bit more local introspection and taking responsibility of their own actions and a bit less blame for others might just instigate the start of a positive trend in the area.

I hate when I see these things about Southern Ohio or West Virginia, as my first inclination is looking to see if someone I knew was featured. I grew up an hour north of Minford, I've ran events on that track, had friends in college from there. I hate seeing this happen, though it's across the whole country and not just my little corner of the tri-state. 

Stories like these just break my heart, reminding me of those I've lost, and for those I know who made it back to sober living, and for the rest of us who live with the losses of those who didn't make it.

I graduated from High School in Burlington, Vermont in 2001 and experienced many of the same things recounted here. For whatever reason we had tremendous access to this stuff and had no clue of the potency. Heroin was never in same universe let alone the same sentence. The usage crossed all socio economic and racial lines and we did it for the same reason most high schoolers do any type of drug - we were mostly just bored. Blame the kids for making poor decisions but drugs have always been part of the American High School experience and they will continue to be. Why is it so different this time? The only difference I can see is that no one at the time realized the potency of what we were ingesting and those who did, failed.
replies: [{'commentID': 103936754, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103936754, 'userID': 80678622, 'userDisplayName': 'Doug', 'userLocation': 'Littleton, Colorado', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\\//>', 'commentBody': '@A the difference is that the former favorites like last, marijuana, even mdma don’t kill at nearly the same rates as the drugs that are currently popular. Experimenting with acid, mushrooms, pot, and a couple of Molly’s isn’t going to form lifelong addiction leading to incarceration and death. Opiates, the drug du jour, almost certainly I will.', 'createDate': '1575359989', 'updateDate': '1582476620', 'approveDate': '1575366946', 'recommendations': 13, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103935873, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'A', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103936754', 'isAnonymous': False}]

commentBody: It would be interesting to hear from the former students who did not participate in drug use in high school why they think they did not.  How did they respond when someone offered them drugs? What did they think? What did they say to the person who offered them the drugs? What did they say to themselves? Why do they think they didn’t participate in drug use when so many others did? What do they think accounts for the difference in their response?

A small side thought is,  power of peer pressure coupled with weak parenting.  What I noticed in many of the boys' photos was that many were sporting this odd hair style.  Conformity. and when the drugs started appearing, conformity.  And how a parent could not notice that their 9 year old was smoking pot…  there was a lot of decay in the fabric of that community when those kids were born. they were lambs to the slaughter
Where was this sympathy during the Crack epidemic?

commentBody: Settlements must be reached that directly compensate the victims of addiction to pay for detox, lifetime addiction treatment, and other medical costs such as insurance, deductibles and out of pocket, education and counseling.
replies:
[{'commentID': 103935631, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103935631, 'userID': 72418709, 'userDisplayName': 'Sasha', 'userLocation': 'CA', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\//>', 'commentBody': '@Dannybill Not every pharmaceutical company is at fault and Society contributed to this problem as well. A decade ago MD's were being sued  because they didn't treat pain aggressively enough. All MD's then had to take courses in pain management and Hospitals had to use pain as the 5th vital signs per regulatory agencies. Purdue certainly took financial advantage and marketed aggressively; a percentage of physicians over prescribed to line their pockets but they are outliers; Health Insurance Companies never covered addiction treatment or Mental Health issues adequately nor do they reimburse adequately even now.  Lastly, the communities affected often are in Red States (Oklahoma) who fought against the Affordable Care Act which actually did finally cover Mental health care and addiction if not to the extent it should have been funded. Multiple factors are in play here. Massive indiscriminate "settlements" hurts us all when Pharma raises drug prices even more to cover the lawsuits.', 'createDate': '1575346106', 'updateDate': '1576978836', 'approveDate': '1575346107', 'recommendations': 12, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103935179, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'Dannybill', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103935631', 'isAnonymous': False}, {'commentID': 103936144, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103936144, 'userID': 41188, 'userDisplayName': 'Steve', 'userLocation': 'New York', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\//>', 'commentBody': '@Sasha 

You can count on the fingers of one hand the number of doctors successfully sued for not providing adequate pain management.  And most physicians have received little if any education on pain management although this was identified as a major problem over 30 years ago.', 'createDate': '1575350415', 'updateDate': '1576543900', 'approveDate': '1575350416', 'recommendations': 7, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103935631, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'Dannybill', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103936144', 'isAnonymous': False}, {'commentID': 103936138, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103936138, 'userID': 41188, 'userDisplayName': 'Steve', 'userLocation': 'New York', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\//>', 'commentBody': "@Dannybill 

Addiction is a disease.  Shouldn't those things be paid for by health insurance the same as the treatments of other diseases are?", 'createDate': '1575350326', 'updateDate': '1583070020', 'approveDate': '1575350466', 'recommendations': 7, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103935179, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'Dannybill', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103936138', 'isAnonymous': False}]

commentBody:
I grew up about a half hour from Scioto County. I am sick of people coming to southeast OH & WV for the answers for drugs, populism, poverty, etc & only magnifying the suffering, offering no solutions or hope & solidifying a reputation for the region that will take decades to undo. It's disgusting & awful for the morale of communities like Scioto County & Portsmouth to be called the poster child of addiction & to have the trauma of real people be the subject of national headlines written by journalists who come to town for a week to profile people in recovery. Reminds me of the scene from The Fighter when Dicky is watching the HBO doc about him and realizes the directors just exploited his pain for something that will only be watched by ppl who .can afford an HBO subscription. 

Instead of journalists that treats disadvantaged and low income communities like visiting a zoo, I recommend writers, filmmakers, etc who offer hope, are intimately connected with the issue, or seek to bring dignity to the people they document.

Why does one use opioids or other drugs?
Life can be unbearable.
There can be pain, sadness, meaninglessness, impulsivity, boredom, exploration, defiance.
Being social--being "liked."
Being different.
Being aware.
The starting line: Ten percent of the population are genetically addiction-prone.
Opioids are medicine.
It is not a crime to use opioids, or other drugs.
It is not a crime to get "high."

Class of ‘95 here. I don’t care at all that people aren’t satisfied with their choice to ingest massive quantities of drugs. We had more education, beginning in fifth grade, as to the physiological and social costs of drugs. We knew better than any generations of humans before us. The choice was ours. It was an informed one.

I taught mathematics at Shawnee State University in Portsmouth Ohio, a few miles west of Minford, starting in 2001. I knew at least one of the students highlighted in the article. Minford High School and other high schools in the surrounding are provided Shawnee State with many of its students. Perhaps, this explains low graduation rates. I knew meth was rampant just by going to the grocery store. Lots of folk with rotting teeth. The news in this article should surprise no one.  I do remember strong intelligent students

When powerful corporations and advertising campaigns enlist the medical community in pushing the illegal use of legal drugs, the playing field for individual choice and responsibility is dangerously skewed. The results of this imbalance are now starkly before us..  

An analogous power imbalance fueled the devastation crack and heroin brought to minority communities.  The decidedly stronger inclination of society to blame the victims when they are black or hispanic is an inclination tainted with racism.  

Certainly individuals are responsible for their choices, but so too  are corporations, professions, and government entities whose power and influence towers above any that individuals wield.

Truly a revelation into my generation and those that came after. I am from the class of 2000, but never saw many problems with drug use in my community in the late 1990s. Fast forward 20 years later as a high school teacher in a nearby community, it's heartbreaking to see parents and students alike suffering from opioid and other addictions. I recall one student, who was still in high school at aged 21 due to his multiple addictions and trying to graduate for the third year in a row. Unfortunately, our efforts did not help him and he dropped out two days before finals. A few years ago, our school also opened a methadone clinic and I observed people across generations utilizing it. It used to baffle me when I first started teaching, but now it's reality. I'm grateful we now have some resources to tackle this issue, though they are never enough.

El capo is in prison for doing the same thing  big pharma did, pushed  narcotics on society. Doctors were the pushers and  dealers. Please spare the argument that it is a legal drug. We need to jail the CEOs of all big pharma companies, if even for a month. Maybe the CEOs, doctors and the marketing department can share a cell with  El Capo...

For the past 30 years, I have  had chronic pain from severe psoriatic arthritis. For about 20 of those years one, or at most two, hydrocodone tablets per day have given me enough relief to function somewhat normally. Hydrocodone has done wonders for me, and it has not led to harder drugs, or prison, or anything negative at all. However, because some people have abused opioids, I can no longer get the low dose I need to go about my life with minimal pain. My doctor is literally afraid of losing his license for prescribing opioids. Can't the powers that be tell the difference between the people who are abusing drugs and the ones who are taking them as they were meant to be used?

commentBody:
Wow. No lectures about the lack family values, pathologies, and  personal responsibility?  No War on Drugs part two? 

 Instead we read articles about lost dreams and what these students could have been. Lies and habtial liars are eventually exposed. The only reason why stories like this keep appearing in newspapers and TV is, who's being affected. The drug abusers and drug profits in the US have always been predominately driven by white drug users.

Police records have shown that black drivers tend to be less likely than white drivers to turn up with guns or drugs when searched at traffic stops. Black drivers are disproportionately pulled over and searched.

These are consequences of living in a corrupt society. White people still think they can "bury" others and avoid the same fate. This is on the beginning, payback is going to be brutal.

What did they think was going to happen????  Did they think?
Is there ever an issue of personal responsibility for one's OWN wellbeing when confronted with temptations from known dangers?
in my oppion as a smoker and only being in 7th grade that parents are failing their kids
This is one of the best pieces of real, raw (yet polished) and novel journailsm I have seen in a long time.

There is a lot of pain out there in America in our isolation during the era of the internet and in our hypocrisy during the Trump era. Meaningful relationships have suffered because of the lack of trust promoted by the greed, arrogance and corruption of our current government.  We will one day soon have a healthy government and we will work to rebuild our communities and the joy of simple things like having real and truthful conversations.

Schools flooded with oxycotin, students get addicted, some get pregnant and the newborn comes out with neonatal abstinence syndrome. McKesson gets off with a fine. Neonatal abstinence syndrome. Newborns addicted to the drugs taken by the mother of the growing fetus. https://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/134/2/e547 After years of investigation of McKesson Corp., led by a Denver-based Drug Enforcement Administration team, over the pharmaceutical giant's distribution of powerful opioid drugs in Colorado and elsewhere, DEA agents say they thought they had gathered enough evidence to warrant criminal charges and fines of more than $1 billion. The DEA probe examined whether San Francisco-based McKesson (NYSE: MCK) failed to report suspicious orders of addictive opioid pain pills by pharmacies that in turn were supplying drug rings for illegal sale. The probe focused on the company's Aurora distribution warehouse initially. “This is the best case we’ve ever had against a major distributor in the history of the [DEA]," David Schiller, who was assistant special agent in charge of the DEA’s Denver field division until his recent retirement, told the Washington Post. Instead, "top attorneys at the DEA and the Justice Department struck a deal earlier this year with the corporation and its powerful lawyers, an agreement that was far more lenient than the [DEA] field division wanted," McKesson's attorneys reached agreement with DEA and Justice Department lawyers..

I love all the shaming comments here from people who surely drink, and alcohol has caused more misery and violence than every drug combined. The most dangerous drug on earth is alcohol. That should be regulated more than heroin (which is to say they should both be legal). The great thing about weed becoming legal is more people do that instead of drinking and it's so much safer for society on every level.

I will absolutely call people out for consuming to excess. As you point out, the drug doesn’t matter. commentBody: These are the children of the Baby Boomer generation and every bit of clumsiness that came with it as we strived and struggled to work hard, get ahead, and find our way in a very different world than that of our parents and grandparents.

How many are aware that the federal government spent over a billion dollars to help communities impacted by drug addicts? https://www.hhs.gov/about/news/2019/09/04/trump-administration-announces-1-8-billion-funding-states-combating-opioid.html These people made poor decisions and chose to get high, but still receive a "bail out" with my federal tax dollars. What a crazy, insane world we live in..
Will these families and individuals be compensated by the Sacklers?   Teva Pharma?   Michael Bloomberg’s largesse; Leon Cooperman?
im in middle school, and drug use is highly affective and im only in 7th grade, juul and weed are the biggest,

We could have been anything, done anything.”
Brooklyn Frazie= but you didn't. Next.

You polled almost 50% of the class, statistically enough to draw some conclusions. How much more compelling, as interesting as they were, the individual stories would have been if we at least knew what the big picture was at the top.
I swear the difference in coverage between the opioid epidemic and the crack epidemic is something that absolutely needs to be addressed.

This was a very powerful way to communicate the toll of the opioid epidemic.  I’ve read many of the comments and it is clear that people are incapable of understanding circumstances that they are fortunate enough not to have experienced.  While I believe every individual should take personal responsibility, blaming the addicted and allowing the drug companies to slide is an extremely narrow perspective. 
      There was a huge profit to be gained by engaging and keeping people addicted to opiates.  It was well understood and strategically marketed by drug companies and overlooked or willfully ignored by the medical community.  Profit at any cost has been allowed for far too long in our society, and we as fellow human beings should try to have a bit more compassion for others who evidently can’t avoid the pitfalls of being human

This has been another typical analysis. The drug exists. Person takes it. Addition. Ruination. Whyyyyy? Ask them specifically why they started, why they kept going, why they didn't stop after a couple. How about asking those who did try it and went, "meh." We never hear from that person. They seem to be rather significant to this discussion.  

Drugs in the times seems to have become purely a supply side issue. Maybe we should think that these people are not so helpless that they lost all historical agency as soon as they came in contact with drugs. Find the secrets to the demand side. Even if addiction is a disease, it need not be a disease like the flu.

This piece makes me angry and saddened at the same time. I feel for the people in this story; the lost lives, broken dreams and a community that's in disarray. However, I'm upset because now that the names are Jillian, Ashley and Jonathan from middle America, the nation sees opioids as a 'health crisis.' No one cared when the names were Jamal, Miguel and Tanisha from Harlem or S. Central LA. In the 80s they were called crack heads and dope fiends. Now that the complexion is different, I hear 'victims.' Even one of the subjects in the piece tried to justify using by saying "I don't do crack. I don't shoot heroin." I guess that made it ok.

Remember, 'crack babies'? Now it's infants suffering from Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome. I see commercials for these treatment centers that are virtual 4 star resorts with white faces strolling beaches and cobblestone paths... In my neighborhood the treatment center was The Hole at Rikers. 

The affects of crack and opioids are the same but it's funny when it hits the mainstream the distain from the 80s and 90s toward black and brown communities becomes sympathy for whites. 
But if that's what it takes for the country to do something significant in this area, so be it. Just remember the white community was not the first victim.
What kind of social and parental structure were these kids living with where one of them reports he started smoking marijuana at 9 years old? This is not normal.

commentBody: Very sad.  Pills (speed, meth, coke, etc.) started to be given to me by friends around age 20 in the early 70s, but after trying most of them once, I just made the choice not to take them.  I didn't like the way they made me feel, and I didn't want to become an addict.  Most importantly, by then I had internalized my "good parent," so that I cared enough about myself to stay off something I recognized could harm me.  But I think that result could have been very different, even with my good parents, if these drugs had been easily available to me as a teenager, as they are today.  Schools need to recognize this all kids are now going to be confronted with drugs at an early age, and must help them figure out a way to deal with that in a more effective way than they have been doing.  Maybe figure out the way to help kids internalize their own "good parents," so they won't want to put themselves at risk of harm.
Corporate greed, the root of all evil.

Well, boo-hoo.

What is common between alcohol, marijuana, tobacco, cocaine, amphetamines, opioids, coffee, and sugar? All are addictive mood-altering substances that, in varying quantities and over varying periods of time, can have debilitating effects on their consumers.

Consumers, not victims. 

It is simply not meaningful to talk about addiction without acknowledging the crucial role of people's conscious choices. Alcohol is available to everyone, but only a few become alcoholics. Addictive substances are available to everyone, but only a few choose to get addicted.
Many of the callous comments below should remind us that that many people still regard addiction as a "weakness" or a "choice."  I guess there is still a need for the "anonymous" groups.
Big Pharma practicing predatory capitalism and acting like a drug cartel. Who would have thought?

These kids should have split for the Coast ..
Medical Cannabis would have saved most of them..

I remember back in the Nixon years, when cops first started breaking down front doors with their battering rams to serve a search warrant, in order to bust some poor hippies sitting on their sofa smoking a joint. The powers that be really made marijuana out to be a really evil thing, including the media.

Fast forward to the opioid crisis. That is a catchall term, which would include heroin users overdosing on Fentanyl and carfentanyl added to their heroin, college kids overdosing on pain pills, high school kids same, all accidental. But in addition to the accidental deaths, there are many suicides which are intentional. Mostly not young people, mostly people who, after the financial crisis took their home, and being too old to start over, tired of working at Home Depot of Walmart, just decided to bag it. And that is different, because they could have just as well used a gun or a rope or a car to commit suicide. It so happens that most just wanted the easiest way out: pills.

Yes blame the drug dealers if that wraps it up neatly for you. People want to get high. That sucking sound of U.S. dollars heading to Mexico, China, etc. is powered by our giant demand for all sorts of drugs which make some people feel better. That won't change as long as the black market exists.

Now ask yourself, do we really need a black market?  I think there's a better way.
When black communities were flooded with crack cocaine the only solutions were death and prison and more despair.
Where were the lost dreams when heroin and crack destroyed non white youth? It is schadenfreude time and the chickens have come home to roost.

We failed our children.  Probably would have been better off just giving out these drugs without a prescription then take them away and push their addicted bodies into injectables like Heroin.  We seem to be an outlier for Hydrocodone and should have prescribed Fentanyl instead and much more sparingly.  The human capital we destroyed is astonishing.

Oxycontin should be banned.

There are better meds for pain relief.

OC is overkill.

And I really don't want to hear the whining of people who praise OC.

You have a stake in this and need to admit you and your docs are part of the problem, not innocent bystanders.

I read a poignant op-ed piece in a local Montana paper in about 2005.  Written by a local HS principal, it implored local youth not to use meth, citing the damage they had seen.  Methamphetamine was ravaging the west then - and continues to do so.   Different place, different drug, same outcome.

The question is 'Why?'   Why are so many youth using drugs and destroying their lives in doing so?    Why are things so much worse in some communities?

Did raising the drinking age to 21 have a negative effect?  Did teen drinking once focus on beer when it was easier to obtain?  Did drugs become an alternative when alcohol was pushed higher out of reach?

Capitalism seems to work as it manages to supply drugs to places barely more than a bus stop in the middle of nowhere  - despite a decades long 'War on Drugs'.

Putting people in jail for using drugs is just so spectacularly wrong and counterproductive. Drug dependency needs to be treated with psychological, medical, and cultural care, not punishment. And we need to connect individual addicts to the society in which they live. Drug dependency is part of a much bigger web of issues; it makes no sense to punish individuals for what is a much bigger cultural and (after someone is addicted) medical problem.
replies: [{'commentID': 103934617, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103934617, 'userID': 22671191, 'userDisplayName': 'Rufus', 'userLocation': 'Planet Earth', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\\//>', 'commentBody': '@Lassie ..."And we need to connect individual addicts to the society in which they live." --- "We" have to do no such thing. "They" did the drug, let them figure it out.', 'createDate': '1575340059', 'updateDate': '1575377785', 'approveDate': '1575341225', 'recommendations': 1, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103933255, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'Lassie', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103934617', 'isAnonymous': False}]

commentBody: When the pharmaceutical companies flooded the market with oxycodone they set some vulnerable people up for trouble. These companies did not flood the market with heroine, cocaine and methamphetamine. Seems like these are the drugs that are killing people, as they always have done. Usually when I read about a death it is not really opioid painkillers that are the cause. If pain pills are involved at all it is because they are used with alcohol. Alcoholism is also a classic killer. Leave the pain pills prescribed for chronic or emergent pain out of this "opioid crisis" narrative. They are not the problem, but it has become a struggle to get appropriate post surgical pain relief these days (cutoffs dropping to 10 days). Enough already.

I grew up in Scioto Co.  I am not an addict, but I saw addiction first hand.  But it was never what it is today.  If you done heroin you were shunned by everyone.  What I dont understand is how was pain managed before opiates?  I dont ever remember anyone dying from pain.  Addiction was classified as a disease just shortly before the opiate addiction explosion.  In my opinion I believe the pharmaceutical companies pushed for that, otherwise, how would they be able to make billions off of it?  Stop and think about it.  The taxpayers are now paying for vivitrol injections at about $1000.00 per month.  Suboxone, which I believe was not supposed to be addictive but is, is about $150.00 per month.  Narcan is about $125.00 for a 2 pack.  How are the opiate addicts going to pay for that?  They arent.  WE ARE.  What about the treatment centers?  Who pays for that?  And the doctors are just as bad for prescribing it all.  Suboxone is just as abused as any other opiate yet people think it is the cure all.  IT ISNT!  It is just a legal way to get stoned.  I will NEVER believe the pharmaceutical companies are not able to find a pain medication that is not addictive.  But without the addiction they lose their customer base.  Until the American people stand up and say enough is enough this problem will never go away.  It is too widely accepted at this point and the addicts have been victimized by society and made to feel it is not their fault.

I'm from Scioto County, and I know Minford, a forested area that is deep into Appalachia. Everyone acknowledges what the root problem has been, a lack of opportunity for those who choose to remain. (Most leave.) Idle hands, plus depression, desperation; an environment where people either spend time in bars or in churches repenting of the time they spent in bars; and especially the proliferation of pill mills created a perfect storm for an addiction crisis.

As I have been writing in comments for months; most addicts make a conscious decision to take drugs. They knew they were illegally obtained and they mixed them with alcohol at parties at which there was no parental supervision. There is a lot of fingerpointing, but even teenagers are responsible for their own behavior.

The Class of 2000. How they’re faring now. Printed in 2019 — as mini-profiles, yes, so you’re under no obligation to analyze the numbers and you have plausible deniability that you are even recommending any particular policy as regards opioids. The prescribing patterns in the late 1990s until 2010 or so were wildly different from today’s. In those years, you could perhaps lay some blame on pharmaceutical companies. A six-year study by the Centers for Disease Control showed prescriptions for narcotic painkillers going DOWN from 2011-2016. At the same time, the graph for  overdose deaths due to heroin and fentanyl looked approximately like this:  /    Since the CDC issued draconian opioid prescribing guidelines in 2016, at least a third of physicians who treated pain have stopped doing so. State and federal authorities have made it increasingly risky and more onerous to prescribe opiates — still the most consistently effective antidote to pain — raiding clinics of ethical doctors and threatening their licenses. This only hurts patients, 99% of whom use their opiate prescriptions responsibly, according to several studies. 191 million Americans were prescribed opiates in 2017. If “1 in 3” are in danger of addiction, there are tens of millions of addicts?  14,502 0D’d from prescriptions, but researchers say that number doesn’t account for stolen or diverted drugs — a pretty big distinction. Blaming Pharma today is a bumper sticker take. And a cruel one.

Not sympathetic or empathetic. I am empathetic to addicts (of any kind), but the oxy addicts? Not any. Likely because I'm smarting from the past. Where were the responsible news outlets/politicians/leaders/talking heads during the crack epidemic of the mid-late 1980's and into the 90's? Oh, I forget: that population were mostly black people. Why bother? Now, the oxy "...public health crisis..." (to quote the NYT) appears to affect a largely white population. I'm completely unmoved by it. Not one iota of sympathy. But, it's about (mostly) white people so it must be serious and needs to be immediately addressed. It's a crisis! (Tongue firmly in cheek.)

You can blame the pharma companies (that's the easy target) and poorly trained/lazy doctors, but how about personal responsibility? Some (white and black) people made a bad choice. And, there were likely contributing economic, social, mental, and cultural factors. Drug addiction does not happen in isolation.

Illicit fentanyl from China and Mexico is causing opioid overdoses, not Rx opioids. It would nice to come across responsible reporting on this subject every once in a while, and a good start would be to explain what opioids are. Feeding the public on the word “opioid” plus “addiction, deaths, abuse and overdoses” with a side of the word “prescription” is disingenuous. It’s like suggesting that there are 1,000 annual deaths due to eating fish, both rotten and untainted. Unless you state that one person died eating untainted fish and 999 died eating rotten fish, the reader will believe that fish, generally, are the problem.

 Pharmaceutical fentanyl is probably the most important and effective medicine for chronic pain patients. Illicit fentanyl, on the other hand. is causing the overdose deaths (being blamed on Rx opioids). Banning licit rx opioids will not reduce overdose deaths caused by illicit opioids; the cause and effect relationship is lacking, and it's about as clever a solution as banning cars to avoid car accidents.

Sorry, but my natural instinct for sympathy for these middleclass white kids is overwhelmed by the egregious unfairness of how black kids have been treated in similar scenarios, ie  with long prison terms, racism, lesser access to services or compassion by the judicial system despite their much greater disadvantages and much less of a safety net when they get out. Until there is some parity my sympathies go all in one direction.
So what. Class of 2000 is about to start hitting forty years of age--if they want to off themselves, then happy hunting.

I grew up in southern Ohio and went to undergrad at Ohio University in Athens Ohio, only 60 miles from Minford. Heroin was already showing up in Athens in the early 90s, killing three college friends by 1996--middle class kids from good families,  Since then, a high school friend and the sister of a close friend have also OD'd on opioids. I've lived in Chicago since 1996 and know NO ONE who's died from opioid addiction here, though heroin was certainly present in Wicker Park when I first arrived. 

Say what you will about the degradation of urban society, but in my experience, rural Ohio is in equally desperate trouble, and has been for a long time. The pharmaceutical companies saw a soft target and took advantage of these people, dumping addictive prescription drugs in communities ill-equipped to deal with the consequences. This wasn't the norm in these communities before oxy contin came on the market and heroin poured into every small town in the U.S. As an extension of the medical field, pharmaceutical companies should have been committed to the oath to "do no harm," but clearly profits were more important than the lives of innocent people who trusted the system.

Wish this generation would stop playing the victim. Opioids in one form or another have been around for centuries. You used to be able to head down to the local opium den for a pipe or two before bedtime. You could buy liquid opioids in the form of laudanum at the grocery store. You want to avoid addiction to opioids? Don’t take them. Quit blaming doctors, your parents, your friends, your priest, your circumstances, etc for something you have control over.
replies: [{'commentID': 103933277, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103933277, 'userID': 67968615, 'userDisplayName': 'Stefan', 'userLocation': 'PA', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\\//>', 'commentBody': '@Pieface this is highly insensitive. First off OxyContin is 50% stronger than morphine, heroine is 2 to 5x stronger, fentanyl is 100x stronger, and Carfentanil is 10,000 times as strong. And that is compared to morphine not laudanum which all sorts of other impurities. Also, when opioids were freely available back then there were horrible addictions problems. You can ask that kids don’t start taking but you can’t simply tell an addict to just stop, like it’s so easy and takes just pure willpower. Addiction is a disease and it co-opts your brain and reward systems.', 'createDate': '1575332703', 'updateDate': '1575337886', 'approveDate': '1575337886', 'recommendations': 0, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103932992, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'Pieface', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103933277', 'isAnonymous': False}]

commentBody:
My older brother is a Vietnam Vet who was wounded and honored for his bravery with a medal and another one for his wound. He now suffers from terrible pain secondary to a number of debilitating maladies including a horrific case of diabetes that has turned his feet black. His MDs in Oregon provided him with morphine until recently, when this opioid crisis caused them to drastically and cowardly reduce his pain meds. 

I'm not sure what he's taking now, but it's no longer morphine but is a weaker opioid. They are apparently more worried that he might or has become addicted to the stronger morphine and they might somehow get in trouble from the DEA. So this 70-year old former US Army Vet will likely spend what remains of his life not only bed-ridden with soon-to-be amputated feet, but also suffering from greater pain than need be just so that he won't become addicted to a stronger opioid. Surely opioid addiction is the least concern someone in his condition and at his age needs to worry about. 

What kind of people are we that allow our wounded vets, or anyone else for that matter, to suffer pain like my brother does just so we can say we are doing something about the scourge of illicit opioid use? This is nothing other than torture sanctioned by the DEA and gutless physicians. It's also an obscene way to treat those who risked their lives for the rest of us. Shame on America.
replies: [{'commentID': 103933318, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103933318, 'userID': 67968615, 'userDisplayName': 'Stefan', 'userLocation': 'PA', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\\//>', 'commentBody': '@Jamie Nichols the only opioid weaker than morphine is codeine. Hydrocodeine is equal strength and OxyContin is stronger.', 'createDate': '1575332897', 'updateDate': '1575336078', 'approveDate': '1575336078', 'recommendations': 0, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103933068, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'Jamie Nichols', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103933318', 'isAnonymous': False}]

commentBody: Absolutely heartbreaking.

So, don't demonize the poppy plant, who knows, 50 years from now this may all look different.

With global warming, I expect the "good kind" of poppy will grow just fine in lots of places.
And now we have vaping. It appears we are an addictive species unconcerned with our own behavior and its consequences.

What a creative, compelling way to dramatize the tragic, yet alluring web of chemical addiction! These behaviors seem to reach way beyond the "medicine cabinet" model of diversion -- into ill-considered psycho-socio dynamics of significant risk-taking propensity. That's enough to challenge the efficacy, to a degree, of traditional prevention and regulatory strategies.

Elected officials could showcase on their websites -- constituent stories of successful recovery, and of those who did not die in vain.

Nobody is forced to take drugs. Everyone knows how addictive drugs are and how they will destroy your body and life.  What is wrong with people and our way of living that people think they need drugs to make it bearable? How do numbers in the U.S. compare to other countries? I suspect there must be a systemic underlying problem.
replies: [{'commentID': 103933497, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103933497, 'userID': 49354039, 'userDisplayName': 'Adam Wright', 'userLocation': 'San Rafael', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\\//>', 'commentBody': "@Faraday 187 It's all countries. In fact, the need to get high is even found in other species of mammals, who use it for a variety of purposes, including a way to grieve.\n\nIt's a part of human nature.", 'createDate': '1575334005', 'updateDate': '1575336079', 'approveDate': '1575336079', 'recommendations': 0, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103932558, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'Faraday 187', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103933497', 'isAnonymous': False}]

commentBody: The sad thing about all of this is there are people who are truly in pain, like my 80 year old mom, and opioids add to her quality of life, but because of this abuse even she was forced off a drug that was making her life bearable. That just stinks. I'm torn on who to blame. I do understand the argument against big pharma but at the end of the day we all make choices and we all must live with them.
replies: [{'commentID': 103935205, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103935205, 'userID': 63842161, 'userDisplayName': 'NotSoCrazy', 'userLocation': 'Massachusetts', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\\//>', 'commentBody': "@Tim - My point will sound lame compared to your mom's issues but I am on board. OK.  I'm sorry for all of the people who got themselves addicted to opioids or its evil cousin fentanyl.  I'm also sorry for all the people who have diabetes from eating fast food and drinking soda.  But guess what?  Food has a place in this world, we don't ban supermarkets... and so does opioid pain medication.  Boo hoo for me, I'm of a certain age and I'm falling apart. I had hernia surgery and believe me a Tylenol or Ibuprofen was not going to cut it.  Dental work... drilling, pounding and pulling.  I have to argue to get a couple of pills to get me though that first day?  Well, I will argue, I have a stake in this...  I'm sorry you're obese, I'm sorry for heart attacks, but I still deserve a meal.", 'createDate': '1575343519', 'updateDate': '1575397636', 'approveDate': '1575344378', 'recommendations': 1, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103932507, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'Tim', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103935205', 'isAnonymous': False}]

commentBody:
I concur with others that personal responsibility is important.  Part of exercising personal responsibility is being able to make an informed choice. Many of these kids made poor choices (as many of us do at that age)--but  they did so with incomplete information (e.g. the highly addictive nature of the drug that was intentionally supressed.).  So their choice was made all the poorer for a criminal lack of information regarding the harm of the drug. 

As a parent, providing tangible and graphic evidential matter to my kids about the ills of this or that was helpful to them.  Though my kids graduated later (2006,2008), I certainly had no wisdom to offer them on the dangers of these drugs--as none was more broadly communicated at the time.  Further, even medical practitioners were not given such critical information to allow them to make informed medical choices for their clients.

Had the drug's addictiveness been more fully disclosed, it would have been less likely to have been used/abused to the extent that it has been as it would have been put on a controlled substance list given all a heads up as to the danger of such a drub.

This report is well done and eye opening but I am surprised at the lack of personal responsibility of some of these students and more so at the lack of responsibility of the parents, the schools, and our society as a whole that has for years now elevated money over ethics, responsibility, morals, civic duty and collective responsibility.
The opioid problem , as far as I can see, stems from this personal and corporate greed. There were people who knew that Oxytocin was addictive but they allowed it to go to market anyway.
The US and Americans could do a lot better if these personal and civic qualities were brought back into our schools and homes.

All of these beautiful young faces with so much of life ahead, some destroyed, others still dealing with addiction and other living with the pain of the death or imprisonment of a family member or friend. Somehow we need to reach our young people and convince them that they are not invulnerable, that they will not live forever. Unfortunately there are those among us who live in denial and don't want our schools, our churches or other organizations to have frank discussions and education on drug use. We are now faced with a strong network of drug pushers, big pharma and the doctors that act as their dealers.  Drug companies spend $20 billion a year greasing their drug peddlers, the doctors. They spend another $6.1 billion on direct advertising.  We spend $600 billion annually on drug rehab. The only way this ends well is to better regulate these two groups and lessen their grip on Congress. We need to invest some of their profits on education . So far big pharma has gotten a free ride and they make El Chapo look like a corner street drug peddler.

Heartbreaking no doubt.  For some that picked up addictions via drugs legally prescribed / over prescribed this should be a criminal problem. But where is the personal responsibility of the person who is taking drugs to just get high.  We are fighting addiction and drugs the wrong way.

The class of 2000 are nearing age 40, these aren’t teenagers anymore, they don’t have parents watching out for them, and read about Opium Wars in China - the stuff is highly addictive.', 'createDate': '1575327278', 'updateDate': '1576543998', 'approveDate': '1575328092', 'recommendations': 9, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103928095, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'E', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103932165', 'isAnonymous': False}]

commentBody: Yes, this crisis is tragic and the damage it has and is causing to individuals, families and the larger society cannot be measured, but I am exhausted with this ongoing effort to blame the crisis on the pharmaceutical companies and the medical community.  This piece...Class of 2000....clearly demonstrates that the vast majority of addicts, including these then-teenagers, became such through their own actions.  They did not choose to become addicts, but they did choose to abuse a legal pain medicine and did so to achieve a high.  I am blaming the victims (i.e., addicts and overdose deaths)?  No.  I do not see them as victims.  They made conscious choices.  As a society, we cannot cure ourselves of all that afflicts us until we take responsibility for our personal actions.  That applies across the board...drug addiction, obesity, kids not performing well in public schools (i.e., parents get involved with your kids), personal debt, etc.
replies:
[{'commentID': 103930049, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103930049, 'userID': 77698791, 'userDisplayName': 'Jonathan', 'userLocation': 'Minnetonka', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\//>', 'commentBody': '@Bob Straight You are correct, many people chose to abuse this drug and were never prescribed it for medical purposes.  However, most were prescribed these meds endlessly for chronic pain. According to AAFP, 11% of Americans suffer from chronic pain.  For many years these drugs were sold to doctors and repeated to their patients as a safe drug to be on.  Once addicted, and no longer able to control their need, these patients were enabled by being given an endless supply of pills through physicians.  I would suggest you read the AAFP position paper on Chronic Pain Management and Opioid Misuse to become better informed.', 'createDate': '1575318734', 'updateDate': '1576544191', 'approveDate': '1575319923', 'recommendations': 12, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103927671, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'Bob Straight', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103930049', 'isAnonymous': False}, {'commentID': 103930386, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103930386, 'userID': 77531964, 'userDisplayName': 'Mary', 'userLocation': 'New York', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\//>', 'commentBody': '@Bob Straight 
Sorry, but pharmaceutical companies, doctors prescribing opioids too easily are part of the problem. People are indeed responsible for their actions, but it is not always clear to them what the consequences may be. More than 10 years ago, I broke my ankle skiing - it was painful but not intolerable. The doctor gave me a prescription - Oxycontin. I tried the sample he gave me - 2 pills, but did not use it any further. I do not attribute that to willpower, but merely to laziness... I did not go to the pharmacy to fill up the prescription. At the time, I was not even aware there was a risk of addiction - I was just told it would help with the pain. 
A few years earlier, I went to the doctor - complaining about anxiety and depression bouts. He prescribed me some antidepressants - after 2 minutes of conversation. I was amazed at the cocktail of medications I was handed - without much effort or scrutiny. Again, I did not take any, just because I realised I did not have any real mental health issues - just that my job and boss were horrible, and no amount of medication could fix that. I went on vacation instead. Again, at that time, I was not aware of addiction risks. Like firearms, opioids were too easily prescribed and accessible - and they kill. 
I could have gone very easily the same path as these young people.', 'createDate': '1575319979', 'updateDate': '1577371361', 'approveDate': '1575319981', 'recommendations': 34, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103927671, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'Bob Straight', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103930386', 'isAnonymous': False}, {'commentID': 103930698, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103930698, 'userID': 86353306, 'userDisplayName': 'MHB', 'userLocation': 'Knoxville TN', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\//>', 'commentBody': '@Bob Straight 
Obviously there is personal responsibility and these people are paying the price for decisions as are their kids and other family members.  That does not mitigate the fact that enough prescriptions were written for every adult and child to have 123 pills apiece per annum.  I lived there for eight years, I saw first hand the people lined up at the pain clinics - everyone knew including big pharma thus their plea deals.', 'createDate': '1575321186', 'updateDate': '1577371368', 'approveDate': '1575321187', 'recommendations': 22, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103927671, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'Bob Straight', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103930698', 'isAnonymous': False}]

commentBody:
My name is ------- and I am an addict. I am clean for eighteen years because of these twelve steps and the fellowship of Narcotics Anonymous.

Step 1: We admitted we were powerless over drugs—that our lives had become unmanageable.
Step 2: Came to believe that a Power greater than ourselves could restore us to sanity.
Step 3: Made a decision to turn our will and our lives over to the care of God as we understood Him. 
Step 4: Made a searching and fearless moral inventory of ourselves.
Step 5: Admitted to God, to ourselves, and to another human being the exact nature of our wrongs.
Step 6: Were entirely ready to have God remove all these defects of character.
Step 7: Humbly asked Him to remove our shortcomings.
Step 8: Made a list of all persons we had harmed, and became willing to make amends to them all.
Step 9: Made direct amends to such people wherever possible, except when to do so would injure them or others.
Step 10: Continued to take personal inventory and when we were wrong promptly admitted it.
Step 11: Sought through prayer and meditation to improve our conscious contact with God, as we understood Him, praying only for knowledge of His will for us and the power to carry that out.
Step 12: Having had a spiritual awakening as the result of these Steps, we tried to carry this message to alcoholics, and to practice these principles in all our affairs.
I believe that addiction is a disease and I believe that it is contagious.  There is no cure but there is hope.

When are we going to stop allowing large corporations to exploit our weaknesses for profit? We keep allowing this to happen, falling victim to the marketing campaigns that such and such item is safe until 5 years down the road we uncover the lies. Over and over this happens, and we never learn from our mistakes.

The number of opioid prescriptions for Minford should have been a glaring red flag that something was amiss. The medical professionals who were prescribing the drug in the midst of this epidemic should also be prosecuted. What  shame that a whole generation was destroyed over greed.

[{'commentID': 103922276, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103922276, 'userID': 67656641, 'userDisplayName': 'Oracle at Delphi', 'userLocation': 'Seattle', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\//>', 'commentBody': "@Janine

commentBody: We really need more research on addiction - what drives people to want to be high.  Its opioids and heroin now - it will be a new drug in the next decade.  Also, study should include those live in these environments but don't use - how do they make the right choice?  I also remember the 80-90's when crack was blasting through communities of color and remember effects on families.  Not much pity around at that time - lots of "lock 'em up, low morals talk.  Now its impacting white people - maybe some real study of addiction will occur now.

This story is incomplete without telling us where these kids were actually getting the pills. Everyone is assuming it was doctor's prescriptions and pharma's greed but we don't know that. Surely in the interviews with all of these people, someone was asking where they were getting the drugs?

Whatever happened to Health Education?
(Maybe it's still taught, but not everybody listens...or cares.)

Reading this causes me the same confusion I always have when I read about opioids. "It's fun"???? While intellectually understanding the issue its just not something I really understand. 

Imagine reading an entire article about people who had no pain taking advil for "fun" and getting addicted. That's what this is like for me. You'd  think "but I don't understand why it would be used for fun or to "party." What in the world is fun about it? You may intellectually understand that it causes many to get high (but you can't really make yourself believe it)

I've taken opioids after surgery. They cause me to feel exhausted, headachy and sick to my stomach. I never had a single "pleasant" feeling. They made my post surgical pain such that I wasn't screaming but once I  had even a semblance of tolerable (vs intolerable) pain, I stopped taking them. Who wouldn't in my place?

Why do I (and I assume a minority of others) react this way when so few others seem to? That seems a good place to start a study of this scourge.

I wish that it would be made more clear that a very low percentage of people who are in genuine pain become addicted to pain killers. I have seen numbers range from 2% to 7%. Of course they are dependent, but that is not addiction. They are two different things.

Too many people who are in legitimate pain are being denied medication because of all the hysteria going on right now. One of my brothers has been in terrible pain from a motorcycle accident he had in 1977. For many years he was on painkillers and was abruptly cut off a couple of years ago. He was not addicted, but dependent. Now he can barely get out of bed in the morning and suffers all the time. His pain has gotten worse than it has ever been and he is sometimes suicidal. He keeps a loaded gun in his nightstand for the day when he just can't take it anymore. 

One of my neighbors who was in constant, extreme pain couldn't take it anymore and took his electric drill to his head. Someone else I know was cut off and now she can no longer walk.

It's time the DEA, CDC and doctors got a grip on this and stop punishing people in pain because of people who get addicted.

 I, myself, am in awful pain from scoliosis, progressive spinal stenosis and arthritis. I also have bursitis in my hips, and can't walk more than 100 feet without extreme pain. I have nothing to alleviate the pain, and believe me, it's cruel an unusual punishment.
No one made them take opiods.  These healthy young people weren't suffering from acute or intractable pain.  It was a conscious decision, for which they were responsible.

commentBody:
‘OxyContin Just Started Showing Up’

Well, it didn't bring itself. It came from somewhere. It's hard to believe all this addiction was fueled by pills left over from dental surgeries, scavenged from parents' medicine cabinets. The article is talking about people with long lasting addictions to high numbers of pills. Was there a pill mill clinic in the area? Where were all these pills showing up from? 

We had a couple recent cases in my city where the pills were being manufactured by individuals using ingredients from China and a pill press. They said you couldn't tell the difference. Cracking down on doctors won't have any effect on that source.

Adolescence is a rough time, lots of pressures and changes going on. Most kids don't have a good idea of their own mortality or a clear vision of their future yet. Make drugs available and, yes, a lot will use them.

Back in the 60's/70's a lot of us were using drugs to get by, too. I knew a number of people, including my own sister, who didn't survive that period. Seems like we opened the door to a way of life, maybe. Now it's gone to an extreme.

As bad as this may seem, NYT should investigate my northwest Wash DC '84 middle school, Lincoln.  I would venture to day 95% are either in jail, were in prison, are dead, homeless or drugged up zombies. What we like to call - a pox upon our soul... but that's a predominantly Afro American school so who cares. I escaped thanks to hardworking (amazing) mom and my upbringing abroad.  I knew if i hunkered down, remained invisible, I may avoid the carnage.  
Nonetheless, if NY Times readers want a true apocalyptic story and grasping the essence of what lies ahead for a nation overwhelmed by a populace incapable of functioning, pick a year in the mid-eighties in predominantly impoverished Black neighborhoods.  Frankly, it would make this story seem like Mickey Mouse stuff.
Don't put your heads in the sand America, like it or not we will pay dearly for poisoning its people. Crime, chaos and high taxes are the inevitable disease of an dysfunctional society. The indoctrination of Trumptopia is only the beginning. Take it from me - someone who knows nothing about politics or sociology, but a ton about the bond market. Where the world gets its money, and where are hopes are fading.
If only the crack epidemic was written about with the same degree of empathy. But people hooked on crack aren’t as a rule white, are they?

Heartbreaking and yet there is this small not-very-nice voice inside my head that keeps whispering:  "Where were you during the crack epidemic?"  and "Where were you during the AIDS crisis?"  Where was your compassion then?  

As of 2016, about 675,000 people have died of HIV/AIDS in the U.S.
